Pokémon Go Costume Tutorial

Hello! I'm Jessie, and this is my Pokémon Go costume tutorial. I was completely inspired by Ginny Di, so I give her most of the credit here! Feel free to use this tutorial to get you started on your own costume, and if you make a costume, I'd love to see it! Email me here for any questions or comments :)

Let's Get Started

I'm Ninjakittenz

and I'm currently still part of the population addicted to playing Pokémon Go. I made a list of items you'll need for the costume. I did things a little differently than other tutorials to try to keep my costume cheaper, but it still includes all of the pieces. The hat I bought off of Amazon. The shoes I got for around $20 at Target, but I know you can find black shoes with white soles for $10-15 at either Target or Walmart. The rest of the items I got from my local fabric store. I borrowed a sewing machine from someone, and I already had an iron and ironing board. These items aren't absolutely necessary, but they will make your life a lot easier.

What You Need

  • White baseball cap
  • Black gloves
  • Black tights
  • Black shoes with white soles
  • Zippers:
    • Blue - invisible (~20 inches)
    • White - separating (~6-10 inches)
  • Blue fabric (3 yards)
  • White fabric (1 yard)
  • Light grey fabric (1/4 yard)
  • Dark grey fabric (1/4 yard)
  • Dark blue fabric marker
  • White ribbed tank top
  • Yellow ribbon (for the shoe)
  • 1 circular thin piece of wood (for the belt buckle)
  • Yellow and white acrylic paint
  • 1" sew-on snap
  • Blue, light grey, and white clothing thread (3 total)
  • Hot glue gun
  • A beginner's sewing kit (or sewing supplies such as a measuring tape, pins, and thread cutter)
  • Sewing machine (or access to one)

The Hat

I bought the hat for about $5 off of Amazon. It's all white so it's completely customizable for the hat you need to make. I took pieces of paper and cut outlines of the triangles that make up the hat, made sure they fit nicely with some pins, then cut the fabric. For my hat, I needed just 2 different triangles. I was able to flip the triangles to fit each side of the hat. The next part is a little tricky.

I took each triangle of fabric and just hot glued them onto the hat. It sounds simple, but I definitely made a couple mistakes in the process. What made it easy for me was to hot glue the top corner of the fabric to the hat first, align the rest of the fabric, then hot glue the rest of the hat on. It's easy to make little bumps in the fabric, so be sure to put your hand inside of the hat to push the hat outward into it's curved shape. I also did the farthest left side and worked my around from there.

For the brim, I used a piece of paper to make a mock-up of the brim, and I used it as a guide for the curved part near where the Pokémon Go symbol is. I took my 1/4 yard of dark grey fabric, made sure I had enough for my belt by putting it around my waist, then cut the remaining fabric. I have a small waist, so if you need more fabric, get another 1/4 yard (that was the smallest amount they could give me). The remaining fabric was enough to cover the top of the brim and, folding under, the bottom of the brim. Using the paper cut-out of the brim, I cut out a semi-circle chunk for it to fit nicely on top of the brim. I hot glued just the top edge of the brim, near the Pokémon Go symbol. Then I wrapped the fabric around the edge and hot glued my way around until everything was smooth. Take your time on this part! I hot glued very small segments as I went around.

For the yellow symbol on the hat, I used the yellow acrylic paint and some circular items I found around the house to paint it on. Use the edge of the paint brush to make the edges look smooth.

And now you have a hat!

The Belt

I started with the easy part and made the belt buckle. You need yellow and white paint, a circular flat wooden plate, a pencil, and a grey marker. I used various circular items around my house to get the pattern I wanted and then traced a few circles with a pencil. I painted on 2 coats of the yellow and white. When it dried, I did one last coat. When that was dry, I used a dark grey sharpie to outline the bigger circle and tabs. They changed the design of the belt buckle recently, so I kind of went with my own design. You can see in the photo, there is some orange and dark grey that I didn't fully add. You should make your belt buckle how you want it! You can, of course, use my design as a guide.
